title: Young Hockey Star Won't Let Anything Stand In His Way
text:
Young Hockey Star Won't Let Anything Stand In His Way Thursday October 15, 2015 6:18 PM UPDATED: Thursday October 15, 2015 6:19 PM COLUMBUS, Ohio - 
Natural talent exists in sports but some athletes have to work harder than others to get the next level. 
That’s exactly the case when talking about one Ohio hockey player, who wasn’t born as the biggest or fastest kid on the ice. 
But, his efforts have made one thing clear and that’s that he won’t let anything hold him back from the sport he loves. 
12-year-old Ben Stewart, travels three or four days every week from Dayton to Dublin to play competitive hockey with the Ohio AAA Blue Jackets. 
“I’ve learned to get better on the ice I have to work on it, try to work harder and get better," Stewart said. 
Many people have to build up the determination it takes to play at an elite level but Ben Stewart has had that determination since he was born. At birth, he had the umbilical cord wrapped around his arm preventing the arm from growing properly. 
Ben has never been one for making excuses. He wasn’t going to wear a prosthetic arm and he would just have to work that much harder to play the sport he loves. 
Further proving his commitment he was able to convert part of his home into a place for him to train. 
“My basement is a mini hockey rink, I played there a lot, I got used to it and when I got on the ice I just did the same thing as I did in my basement,” Stewart said. 
That system seems to be paying off, as head coach Jeff Christian says he sees improvement in him every day. 
“He’s confident, hockey stuff is coming around and he’s getting more used to the speed and pace, he’s an inspirational story for the rest of the kids," Christian said. 
Ben’s goal has never been to be perfect, but when it comes to playing in the NHL, that’s more like it. 
“If I continue to play with this team, having them make me better I think I could," Stewart said. ©2015 by 10TV.com. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed. Currently in Columbus
